awd_titl_txt: Predicting and Controlling the Coupling Between Dyes and Plasmonic Nanoparticles
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Biteen at the University of Michigan is developing a microscope to measure position and motion of biomolecules in living cells with a super high resolution (at the nanometer scale). This super-resolution microscope combines emerging high-resolution microscopy techniques and the unique properties metal nanoparticles where metal nanoparticles strongly affect the fluorescence emission from nearby dye molecules. Professor Biteen works on using the high-sensitivity microscopy to understand the interaction between metal nanoparticles and the dye molecules and to control coupled emission. She is working toward a real-time, non-perturbative, biocompatible microscope for live-cell imaging. Professor Biteen works closely with undergraduate women students and students from other under-represented minority groups.  She is promoting science as an exciting field to a broad audience by supporting public lectures and developing hands-on demos for middle school girls.

Single-molecule, super-resolution microscopy enables direct investigations of physical and optical effects far below the half-micron diffraction limit of light, but this technique is restricted in practical applications by the limited brightness of probes relative to the background, especially in cellular samples. Plasmonic nanoparticles (NPs) readily produce over hundred-fold field intensity enhancements to brighten proximal dyes, but the modified dye emission also yields localization biases that have not yet been fully characterized due to the limitations of conventional experimental approaches. Professor Biteen is improving the resolution of single-molecule imaging with NP plasmonics. State-of-the-art single-molecule fluorescence experiments on dyes coupled to metal NPs can directly measure the effects of plasmonic NPs on proximal dyes. Therefore, the single-molecule readout can inform models of dye-NP interactions, while at the same time, plasmonic enhancement can improve the single-molecule fluorescence brightness. Professor Biteen is working toward high-accuracy, nanometer-scale, plasmon-enhanced super-resolution microscopy by: (1) measuring the changes in dye molecule intensity, spectrum, direction, and polarization of emission produced by a plasmonic NP, (2) controlling the dye-NP coupling by tuning the excitation polarization and frequency according to the relationships determined in objective 1, and (3) super-resolving the positions and movements of membrane proteins in living cells prepared on plasmonic surfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Fluorescence microscopy is extremely useful for exploring features in living cells, and we combined super-resolution fluorescence microscopy and metal nanoparticles for plasmonic enhancement to attain very high-resolution images in a general, biocompatible approach. Our NSF-funded project achieved accurate, nanometer-scale microscope images in vitro and in cells. This project furthered the field of plasmon-coupled single-molecule microscopy and laid the foundations for the extensions to chirality, which is ubiquitous in biology. The Intellectual Merit of the work was to measure and control changes in single-molecule fluorescence based on coupling to metal nanoparticles: we built a single-molecule polarization microscope capable of discriminating between orthogonal linear polarization states in the emission path; we achieved single-molecule and single-particle spectroscopy in our microscope; we characterized the spectral reshaping and emission polarization rotation of single dye molecules coupled to single plasmonic nanoparticles; we understood this emission coupling with a dipole-dipole interference model in collaboration; and we understood the fluorescent properties of single dye molecules. We subsequently developed an algorithm to accurately locate and measure the intensity of single molecules in living cells by overcoming the challenge posed by backgrounds that fluctuate significantly over time and space given that plasmonic nanoparticles produce fluorescence backgrounds that can be mistaken for dye molecules. Additionally, we tuned non-toxic, biocompatible plasmonic gold nanotriangle arrays created by nanosphere lithography to selectively enhance fluorescent protein tags in the bacterial cell membrane at the resonance wavelength.

We then extended our single-molecule polarimeter to demonstrate the feasibility of single-particle circularly polarized luminescence measurements, based on analyzing the photoluminescence from chiral helicoids to differentiate between left- and right-handed circularly polarized luminescence; and we demonstrated proof-of-principle experiments for the feasibility of measuring the chiral emission of coupled dye-plasmonic nanoparticle systems based on single-molecule fluorescence-detected circular dichroism. Finally, we applied single-molecule microscopy and transient absorption binding imaging to insulin fibrils in solution and curli amyloid fibrils in Escherichia coli to demonstrate proof-of-principle ability to detect these chiral biopolymers in vitro and in vivo.

This multidisciplinary project bridged components from Physics, Chemistry, and Microbiology. In addition to training graduate and undergraduate students in nano-optics in the context of this project and developing lectures and assignments for undergraduate quantum mechanics and thermodynamics, the Broader Impacts of the project were to engage K-12 students and the general public, with a particular focus on girls in elementary and middle school through our involvement in conducting science demos with the UM Association for Women in Science (AWIS); coordinating events during the UM Women+ Excelling More in Math Engineering (FEMMES) Sciences capstone symposium; and coaching for the Washtenaw Elementary Science Olympiad (WESO). We engaged the public via Skype a Scientist, which connects us with students and adults around the nation, and we advanced scientific communication through the University of Michigan Chemistry Science Communication Fellows program and RELATE scientific communication workshops. 

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2024
Modified by: Julie Biteen
